title: Web3 Privacy Fundamentals
description: Understand what privacy means on public blockchains, build a personal threat model, and practice operational security habits.

steps.title: Privacy on Public Chains
steps.description: Understand the privacy model of public blockchains.

conceptCard.title: Public chains are transparent by design
conceptCard.body: Every transaction on Ethereum is visible to everyone. Privacy is not the default — it's something you must actively manage.

steps.title: What's Public and What's Not
steps.description: Learn exactly what data is visible on-chain and what remains off-chain.

conceptCard.title: On-chain vs off-chain data
conceptCard.body: Wallet addresses, transaction amounts, contract interactions, and token balances are all public. Your identity behind an address is not — unless you link it.

skillSuggestion.message: You've learned about on-chain transparency. Add this to your skills?

steps.title: What Privacy Can't Do on Public Chains
steps.description: Understand the fundamental limitations of privacy on transparent ledgers.

conceptCard.title: Privacy has hard limits on public chains
conceptCard.body: You can make linking harder, but you cannot make transactions invisible on a public chain. Understanding these limits prevents false confidence.

steps.title: Build Your Threat Model
steps.description: Create a personal threat model for your on-chain activity.

steps.title: Privacy & Security Checklist
steps.description: Review and implement privacy best practices.

steps.title: Your Privacy Strategy
steps.description: Reflect on what you've learned and write your personal privacy strategy.

skillSuggestion.message: You've completed the privacy track. Add OpSec to your skills?

steps.title: Privacy Knowledge Check
steps.description: Test your understanding of Web3 privacy fundamentals.

questions.question: What information is publicly visible on Ethereum?
options: Wallet addresses, transaction amounts, and contract interactions
Nothing — Ethereum is private by default
questions.correctAnswer: Wallet addresses, transaction amounts, and contract interactions
questions.explanation: Ethereum is a public chain — all transaction data including addresses, amounts, and contract calls are visible to anyone.

questions.question: True or False: Using a new wallet address for each transaction guarantees complete privacy.
questions.explanation: Using different addresses helps but doesn't guarantee privacy. Chain analysis can still link addresses through funding patterns, timing, and amounts.

questions.question: What is the biggest risk of using an ENS name on your main wallet?
options: It publicly links your human-readable identity to on-chain activity
questions.correctAnswer: It publicly links your human-readable identity to on-chain activity
questions.explanation: ENS names create a permanent public link between a recognizable name and all activity on that address.

questions.question: Why should you use separate wallets for different purposes?
options: To prevent on-chain activity from being linked across contexts
Because each wallet can only hold one token type
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent on-chain activity from being linked across contexts
questions.explanation: Separate wallets compartmentalize your on-chain identity, making it harder to build a complete profile of your activity.

questions.question: What does a personal threat model help you do?
options: Prioritize which privacy risks to address based on likelihood and impact
questions.correctAnswer: Prioritize which privacy risks to address based on likelihood and impact
questions.explanation: A threat model helps you identify and prioritize risks so you can focus your efforts on the threats that matter most to you.

badge.name: Web3 Privacy
badge.description: Completed the Web3 Privacy Fundamentals track and demonstrated understanding of on-chain privacy, threat modeling, and operational security.
